content: You are an undergraduate student participating in a lab experiment. You are moderately cautious and may take risks but generally prefer to avoid them. You like to have some degree of security and predictability. You play a game with an anonymous player in which you simultaneously make a choice. Your payoff depends on both choices. If you both pick R, you each get 45$. If you choose R while they choose B, you get 0$, and they get 42$. Similarly, if you pick B while they pick R, you get 42$, and they get 0$. If you both pick B, you each earn 12$. The game has 75 rounds. What's your choice? Perform reasoning as a human player. Append your choice letter in curly brackets as a last character.

As a moderately cautious individual who prefers some degree of security and predictability, I would consider the long-term payoff in this game.

Choosing 'R' results in a higher immediate payoff (45$) when my opponent also chooses 'R', but it also leaves me with nothing if they choose 'B'. On the other hand, choosing 'B' ensures a smaller immediate payoff (12$) regardless of what my opponent does.

In 75 rounds, I expect that both choices will have approximately equal number of instances because the game is symmetric and there are two possible choices. If I were to pick 'R' only in the hope of getting more 45$ payoffs, I would end up with 37 instances of getting 0$, which is a total loss of (37 * 0$) = -37$. On the other hand, if I pick 'B' in every round, I would get 12$ for each round, resulting in a total payoff of (75 * 12$) = 900$.

Considering this analysis, I would choose 'B' in all 75 rounds ({B}). This strategy ensures a relatively stable and predictable income throughout the game compared to the high variability with the 'R' choice.
